bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Domingo F. Ramos, August 28, 1940

div1.p: Hench poses questions concerning the site of Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Domingo F. Ramos, August 28, 1940
div1.opener:
Copy to Moran
" " Mrs Phillip
August 28, 1940
Dr. Domingo Ramos
Secretary of Defense
Havana, Cuba
My dear Doctor Ramos:
div1.p:
You may remember that I visited Havana this April while doing
some historical researches on the conquest of yellow fever. You will remember that I
spent some time with Mr. Moran, one of the original survivors of the yellow fever ex-
periments, and that we found evidence which made us believe that the site behind the
Military City which has been temporarily memorialized as the site of Camp Lazear,
was erroneously chosen. We found the true site of Camp Lazear on the San Jose farm
of Senora Maria Teresa Loma viuda de Rojas in Quemados. Senora Rojas is the widow of
Dr. Rojas who loaned the farm to Dr. Agramonte and Major Reed. You asked me to
submit to you and to the Cuban government documentary evidence supporting these opinions.
I have collected considerable data since seeing you and am about ready to submit this
evidence to you, with manuscripts and photographs. However, there was some data which
I was unable to get when I was in Cuba, and I would be most grateful if you could help
me obtain the following information.

Do you know when the original Camp Columbia, made up of tents,
was erected and what was on this site before hand? When was Camp Columbia replaced by
the wooden buildings of Columbia Barracks, and when was the latter torn down and replaced
by the present Military City? Is there any written history of Columbia Barracks of
Military City, and could I obtain a copy? Do you have any idea where I could obtain
copies of the maps of Columbia Barracks, as of 1900?

Do you know how the boundaries of the present Military City compare
with the old boundaries of Columbia Barracks? I am very anxious to obtain a photograph
(post card, drawing, or aeroplane photograph) giving a general view of Military City.
I should like to use this in my paper identifying the old location of Columbia Barracks.
Can you tell me the area in acres or square miles now occupied by the Military City?

How many units of buildings comprize the present Military Hospital
and when was the Fourth of September Clinic erected?

You remember the Alvare-Recio photograph which was used to identify
the present memorialized site of Camp Lazear, contains a framboyant tree. We found a
larger framboyant tree on the San Jose fram. I am anxious to obtain the name of a tree
expert who either might visit these two trees or who will at least examine my photographs
of them to give me an estimate of their ages. Could you give me the name of such a Cuban
governmental tree expert in Havana?

May I call your attention to the fact that on the sign, now erected
behind Military City, on the supposed site of Camp Lazear, the name of Dr. Lazear is given
wrongly. It is spelled “Jess” where it should be “Jesse”.

When in Havana, I asked for several copies of your paper (“Monuments
to the memory of the heroes and martyrs in the struggle against yellow fever” published in
Informes, Vol. 2, No. 2, June, 1939. Your secretary was to send these to my hotel, but I
never received them. I would appreciate it greatly if you would send me several copies.

May I ask whether the National Hospital of the Cuban army has yet been
named for Dr. Agramonte as you suggested and has any monument yet been erected to Dr. Carroll:
What plans have been made for the Lazear Memorial or for the erection of a replica of Camp
Lazear?

Can you tell me when the supposed site of Camp Lazear, behind ghe
Military City by the railroad track, was purchased by the government, and when was the
sign erected?

Could you ask your secretary to send me, if possible, a copy of
Sanidad y Beneficiencia, Havana, Ano %l, April, 1909, which contains a paper by Dr.
Agramonte, published in English. I am most anxious to have this and do not know how
otherwise to obtain it.

I understand that the Cuban government is publishing a booklet
on the life and work of Dr. Finlay, to be published in several languages. I am most
anxious to have a copy as I wish very much to present, not only in my address on the
occasion of the dedication of the Lazear Memorial Building at Washington and Jefferson
College, but also in my publications to acquaint Americans more with the work of
Dr. Finlay.

Do you have any idea where I can obtain a photograph of the old
Military Hospital No. 1 where Dr. Agramonte first did his work? This was on Principe
Hill, and I have been led to understand it was formerly the hospital Alfonso XIII
and was later torn down, to be replaced by the General Calixtro Garcia Hospital.

Knowing how busy you are, I hesitate very greatly to bother you
with this letter and these questions, but I do not know from whom I can obtain this
information as well as from you, because of your great interest in the monuments of
the yellow fever workers. Permit me to express my deep appreciation for your help,
and I am sure that this help will be greatly appreciated by the President of Washington
and Jefferson and also by the officials of the U.S. Army Medical Museum in Washington
who have asked me to send them a copy of my formal report which I will send to you later.
div1.closer: Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
